reporting-org.narrative: European Centre for Development Policy Management (ECDPM)

title.narrative: 17. ACP-EU relations

description.narrative: This work stream is derived from the ECDPM impact area effective frameworks and tools for international cooperation. It aims to contribute to the following changes:1) The ACP-EU partnership is transformed into a modern, mutually beneficial (set of) framework(s) for international cooperation aligned to the Agenda 2030; the focus is in particular on the “A”, the “C” and the P” and their evolving interests in the partnership with Europe. 2) EU policy frameworks for dealing with Africa are made more coherent and effective; specifically looking into how the longstanding partnership with the “ACP” can be integrated in a coherent and effective way into the evolving EU external action. The focus here is on Europe, hence the need to establish a close link with the work streams on Integrated European External Action and EU development policy and practice.

description.narrative: Biennial outcome narrative by ECDPM assessing the progress made towards the envisaged outcomes in the period: 2018-01-01 - 2019-01-24

title.narrative: Qualitative indicator

comment.narrative: ECDPM reports biennially on its outcomes in a narrative

ACP-EU Relations 1. Context and outcome areas This work stream is primarily concerned with “effective international cooperation frameworks”, focusing on the process of renewing the Africa Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) - EU partnership, the “Cotonou framework”, beyond 2020. This postcolonial, donor-recipient arrangement it is argued and debated has lost momentum over time. Discussions are ongoing on the question whether it is still “fit for purpose” to deal with regionalisation dynamics (particularly on the African continent) and with the global agenda 2030 (which requires negotiation of common interests, multi-actor and multi-level partnerships as well as diversified sources of funding). The most important change to which we want to contribute is to have an open-ended, evidence-based and forward looking political decision-making process on how to design a new Post-Cotonou framework that is aligned to current geopolitical realities and responsive to the interests of the EU, Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific countries and regions. 2. ECDPM contributions in the outcome areas A wide range of activities have been undertaken and outputs generated to inform all relevant stakeholders on what is at stake in Post-Cotonou; to promote inclusive dialogues; to build shared understanding and facilitate prospective thinking; and to empower some of the key stakeholders (particularly the AU) to participate in the process. Yet this work faced a number of political realities and forces that are of a rather conservative nature. Key decision-makers (EU and African states from the ACP) so far prefer to stick to continuing the ACP-EU model (instead of opting for regionalisation). As a result, the prospects of using this renewal of the ACP-EU partnership in a transformative way are - for the moment - quite dim. ECDPM has been using different methods (seminars, papers, dialogues) to pinpoint to the coherence challenges the EU faces with regard to the ACP. Providing evidence based diagnostics of the ACP-EU partnership has not been effective so far. The EU has dropped the ACP as a key actor in all its main policy documents, in its organograms and in its actual external action practice (e.g. both the trade and political cooperation components of the Cotonou Partnership Agreement have been regionalised). Also in the future plans for the next EU budget (2021-2027) the ACP disappears as targeted group with its own financing instrument. Yet despite all this, the EU persists to go for a renewed deal with the ACP. 3. Did you consider gender issues during the process of engagement? One of the content issues we look at in the Post-Cotonou debate is the place and weight that Europe will give to promoting its value-driven agenda on sexual and reproductive health rights (SRHR) towards the ACP group and in the three regional protocols to be negotiated with Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific. A paper will be produced by end of November 2018 to frame this debate and look at key policy implications.
